div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: AN EGYPTIAN LOURDES.
div.p: "Sic vos non vobis" writes from Alex­andria :—The members of the Alexandrian Archaeological Society who have read the account in the "Egyptian Gazette" of the exploration of the site of the church of St. Menas under the heading, "An Egyptian Lourdes' must have observed the way in which the author studiously ignores the Bulletin No. 6 for 1904. He has, apparently, taken his all from the two pamphlets he refers to, published by one of the explorers in 1906-7 in which the only allusion to the Bulletin is mode for the express purpose of denouncing the inaccuracy of the site of the ruins as indicated in the map attached to it.

This would have been scarcely generous, m even courteous, if the map had pretended to 'indicate the precise site of the Church of St, Menas, which was not the case, and savours on the part of the explorers of a thirst for per sonal notoriety rather than of simple ambition to aid in filling up a gap in our local archaeology.

In 1904 the Society published in its Bul­letin for that year a paper written by one of its members in April of the same year, calling attention to the fine collection of Menas ampullae in the Graeco-Roman Museum, and giving descriptions and photographic illustrations of a selection of the most important of them by the late head of the Numismntic Department. The paper contained, also, a

biographical notice of St. Menas, as the Patron Saint of Lower Egypt, and an account of the Church by an Arab author of the tenth or eleventh century (cited by Mrs. Butcher in her "Story of the Church of Egypt" and by Dr. Butler in his "Arab Conquest of Egypt" from Quatremere); concluding by an appeal to the Society for an exploration of the site as an object suitable for the expenditure of its funds. A white marble tablet, amongst other relics with the typical figures of the Saint with his two procumbent camels carved on it in relief, had, lately, been brought from Ma-rout to Mex and thence to the museum,clearly indicating that the site might be looked for at no great distance.

The president of the Society wrote officially to the head of the Egyptian Coast­guards sending a copy of the' Bulletin and map and asking for the aid of his de­partment, which includes a Camel Corps, in a search for the site of the Church' with a view to its exploration when discovered.

The request was at once acceded to, and one of the European inspectors of the department indicated as having been in structed to aid the Society in carrying out its wishes. What steps, were taken by the official in this direction I have not ascer­tained.

We now learn from the author of "An Egyptian Lourdes" that, early in 1905, the two archaeologists at present engaged on the site left Frankfort with the object of exploring Cyrenaica ; but, failing in that object "had another scheme in reserve, which was to find the site of Karm Abu Mina, and so they set out for Egypt."

Whether this "scheme in reserve," had really formed part of the original design of the archaeologists, in accordance with their instruc­tions from Frankfort, may well be doubted as the A. A. Society's Bulletin was already in the hands of the archaeological societies of Europe, and it would hardly have been in accordance with the courtesy invariably dis­played by foreign scientific societies "inter se" that an exploration, under the auspices of a European city, should have been organised, under the above circumstances, without notify­ing the intention to Alexandria.

There was, however no reason why the . bulletin of the A. A.S. should not have aroused an interest in Frankfort as to the measures the society had in view for exploring the site, and every reason why the "would be." explorers of Cyrenaica should prefer not to return with empty hands to Frankfort whilst there was a prospect of successfully utilising their funds.

In an extremely well written and interesting account of the results of the explorations down to April 1906, by an active member of the Alexandria Society, which appeared in the "Egyptian Gazette" of 24 April 1906, he observes that the author of the paper on the site of St. Menas Church in the Bulletin No. 6 foe 1904 "could certainly not suppose that at that very time an expedition was covering the whole of the Walad Ali Desert, and Mariout, with the definite object of discovering the historical city of St. Menas." This is an indis­putable fact, considering that the paper was completed in April 1904, and only awaited the reduction in France of the illustrative photos : and the publication of the Bulletin a few months later, whilst the desert exploring party did not leave Alexandria until May 7 * 1905, discovering the ruins a month later.

The party is stated in the "Gazette" to have "received valuable assistance" from the vice- president of the Archaeological Society, pre­sumably in a private capacity, as no com­munication regarding the intended exploration was made to the society.

The author of the "Egyptian Lourdes" credits the explorers with having discovered the ruins of a spot called Boumna by the Bedaween ;but they would, surely, repudiate such a notion, being well aware of the visit of Jean Raymond Pacho to the ruins of Boumna (under that identical name) published in 1827, shortly after his death, in the account of his journey from Alexandria and Cyrenai­ca What the. explorers have lone is to iden­tify the ruins of Boumna into the site of the three towns and church described by the Arab historian and to excavate the site of Menas Church as proposed in the Bulletin of the A A.S. and far be it from me to seek ' to depreciate the archeological importance and interest of the successful result, though the splendid marble statue of the 8aint with his camels, with many other statues described by the above historian, the discovery of which would have greatly enhanced the value of the discoveries by identifying beyond the possibility of doubt the "Sanctum Sanctorum" of the church, have not yet been found.

The title of "An Egyptian Lourdes," based on a not improbable conjecture, as applied to the Church of St. Menas, may, however, without any conjecture, be applied to that of "Menouthis" of which we have a contemporary historical account at the begining of the seventh century, by Sofronius, Patriarch of Jerusalem, directly associating it with the bones of two Alexandrian martyrs, 8t. John and St. Cyrus, (Abu Kir wa, Hanna) from whom the modern village and promontorv of Abukir have inherited their name. Alex­andrian archaelogists will be familiar with the lively account of the miracles performed in the days through the mediun of the two Saints, given by Lumbroso in his " L'Egitto dei Greci e dei Romani. " 1882-95, which have never yet been surpassed by either "La Salette" or " Lourdes. ''

But Lumbroso, Heroutsos, and other distin­guished Graeco- Roman scholars who have written learned and valuable papers on the ancient history of the Alexandrian district, are alike ignored with the local Archaelogical Society, in order that the authors of the St. Menas exploration may pose as the pioneers of early Christian archaelogy in Alexandrian Egypt.

div.head: The Matarieh Disaster.
div.p: The Mohamedan Benevolent Society decided at its last meeting to grant a sum of £400 to the Matarieh inhabitants, and opened a subscrip­tion list, which has reached £108. The money has been remitted to the moudir of the province.

div.head: Alexandria Archaeological Society
div.p: The general meeting of the Alexandria Archaeological Society will be held this after­noon at half past five at the Alexandria Mu­seum, when the report for last year will he lead and a committee appointed for the present year.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: Between January 1 and April 18, 423,577 tons of coal were imported into Egypt, of which 229,518 tons were Welsh, 81,114 Newcastle, 71,788 Yorkshire, 19,329 Scotch, and 21,828 other qualities. During the corresponding period of last year the coal imports totalled 418,090 tons.

div.head: Crsak Theological School
div.p: The foundation stone of the Hellenic pre­paratory school which is being given to the greek community by Mr. George Zervudachi may be laid to-morrow afternoon at Chatby at five o'clock. All the Greek notables of Alex­andria will attend at this ceremony, which will tie most brilliant.

div.head: Brindisi Mall
div.p: The Brindisi mail for Europe via Port Said will close at 3.15 p.m. to-morrow at the G.P.O., Alexandria, for ordinary letters and one hour earlier for registered correspondence. Money orders and insured articles will not be received after midday to-morrow, and parcels must be posted by 6 o'clock to-night.

div.head: A Pre-Emption Case.
div.p: It will be remembered that the Daira Khassa recently bought a large estate from the Aboukir Estate Company, and that Prince Omar Toussoun exerted his right of pre-emption on the land as he held land bordering the property. The Daira Khassa contested that the pre­emption was premature, the sale not having as yet been registered in the Tribunals. The Court of Appeal, however, has decided in favour of the Prince one the grounds that pre-emption is legal in the case of non-registration provided that the party is cognisant of the sale,

div.head: A Serious Charge.
div.p: "Al Watan" and "Al Zaher" publish some extraordinary statements about a Member of Parliament, which were the subject of comment by "Al Mokattam" yesterday. The reflections passed by "Al Watan" and "Al Zaher" as to the motives which have inspired a certain Member of Parliament to take an interest in Egypt are of so grave a character as to be quite incredible and however much some persons may disagree with this Member of Parliament's tactics in regard to Egypt, no Englishman will for a moment believe the grave imputations, which "Al Zaher" and "Al Watan" cast on a Member of Parliament.

div.head: Exoavations at Assouan
div.p: M. Clermonte-Ganneau has presented a report of his recent archaeological campaign in Upper Egypt to the Academie des Inscriptions et Belles-Lettres at Paris. He went to the island of Elephantine at Assouan in order to find the remains of an Aramaic Colony there whose members had erected an altar to Jehovah It was hoped to find some papyri, which would shed some light on this ancient and interesting settlement. According to his report there ii no longer any doubt about the existence of such a colony on the island but further researches are needed to discover papyri. After a three months, campaign he obtained a variety of objects dating from various epochs of Egyptian history. These include two fine statues covered with inscriptions and in necropolis of rams all carefully mummified and interred in granite coffins. The ram was the sacra animal of the divinity of Elephantine.

div.head: LORDD CROMER'S DEPARTURE.
MEETING AT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: Yesterday a well attended and representative meeting of British subjects resident in Alex­andria and the neighbourhood was held at the British Club to express regret at Lord Cromer's departure Mr. Gould opened the meeting with the following speech :—

"We are met together to day to consider a proposal to send an address to Lord Cromer on the occasion of his retirement from Egypt. This meeting has been called at the instance of several British subjects, who met informally some days ago, and who were of opinion that such an address should be presented. They were also of opinion that it should be a sponta­neous action on the part of the British com­munity here and not in any way an official movement. They therefore approached: the authorities of the British Club and obtained their leave to call the necessary public meeting here. They have further, I am informed, prepar­ed a draft address to be submitted to this meeting.

"I would now suggest that some private member of the community should be invited to take the chair and I intended to propose that Mr. Moss should be asked to do this. Mr. Molts, however, has been unavoidably prevented from coming here to-day and he expresses his very great regret. 1 propose, therefore, that Mr. Percy Carver should be asked to take the chair at this meeting for Mr. Moss, and that that gentleman, as one of the oldest British residents, should act as president for -any further action in this matter.

Mr. Percy Carver being thus called to the chair called upon Mr. Foster as the chairman of the informal preliminary meeting to submit to the meeting the draft address, which he proposed that he should read,' after any in­troductory remarks he might choose to make, and if the address should be approved, every­body present would be asked to sign it

Mr. Foster said that the meeting had been convened to decide what was to be done. It had been thought advisable to come before the meeting with the complete project. This was a short letter couched in simple terms to Lord Cromer expressing regret at his leaving Egypt This could be signed by all British subjects resident in Alexandria. The whole will be bound together, the firm of Messrs Waterlow having kindly undertaken to do so The volume is to be bound in morocco leather and stamped 'Earl of Cromer 1883-1907."
After the address had been read and approved with hearty and unanimous applause, the meeting was dissolved and all present appended their signatures.

The address will remain at the British Club to-day and to-morrow, at the Union Club on Monday and Tuesday and at the Khedivial Club on Wednesday. The address which will be at the hall porters of the Club can he signed by any British subject, whether lie be a member of the club or not
The following are the terms of the address :—
We the undersigned British subjects, resi­dent in Alexandria and the neighbourhood, desire to express the profound regret with which we have received the announcement of your Lordships resignation.
With respect and gratitude we testify our deep sense of the wisdom, vigour, and patience that have characterized your services in Egypt, which under conditions of incredible difficulty,
have achieved so great a work for the well being of those who dwell in this land.

We of Alexandria most gratefully remember the keen and sustained interest you have taken in all that concerns the British Community, and it will always be a source of pride to us to think that we have resided in Egypt during your Lordship's distinguished tenure of Office.

Our regret at your Lordship's departure is deepened by the fact that it is due to failure of health and we respectfully beg to convey to , your Lordship our heartfelt sympathy and our most sincere wishes for your speedy and complete recovery.

div.head: MALTESE TESTIMONY.
div.p: The Maltese Benevolent Society sent a telegram expressing their regret at Lord : Cromer's departure through their president, Mr Leander Camilleri, to which his Lordship replied telegraphically expressing his cordial thanks.

div.head: A NEW CANAL.
div.p: The correspondent of the "New York Herald'' at Berlin states that the schemes for cutting a new canal through the isthmus of Suez with the assistance of only English capital has taken definite shape. The concession will be granted shortly. This news has caused considerable sensation at Berlin where the opinion is that if the project is carried out it will compete
with the Bagdad railway.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner Menes sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon and is due here on Tuesday morning with passengers, mails and general cargo.

div.head: EGYPT IN PARLIAMENT.
APPROPRIATION OF LAND.
div.p: The following are questions asked on the 16th and 18th inst in the House of Commons on Egyptian matters and their answers :—

Mr. John Robertson,— To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether, in the case of an official appropriation of land at Khartoum, the Governor, Stanton Bey, has informed the natives concerned that the price paid to them is simple bakshish, given at the pleasure of the Government.

Sir Edward Grey:— I have no informtion on the subject. If the Hon. Member will supply me with particulars of what appropriation of land is referred to, I will enquire what the circumstances and conditions of the appropria­tion were.

Mr. John Robertson,— To ask Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether the natives at Khartoum have requested the Government to establish schools for girls, and have been referred to the Protestant schools controlled by missionary organisations where the children are taught solely on Christian lines.

Mr. John Robertson.— To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether the Soudan Government has appropriated for public purposes 1,800 feddans of land North of the Blue and White Niles, and has paid for it, not at the market rate, but at prices fixed by the officials at their pleasure; and whether at Khartoum North (Halfayah) the Government has forcibly appropriated land from native 'owners at £2 per feddan and has sold it for prices of £15 or more per feddan to the Model Farming Association.

Mr. John Robertson,—To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether, since the conquest of the Soudan, the Administration has confiscated the lands and property formerly, and in large part before the time of the Mahdi, owned by the Wakf,—that is to say, the Moslem ecclesiastical organisation which received be­quests and gifts from Moslems for religious or charitable purposes; and, if so, whether the property thus confiscated could not be devoted to purposes of education.

Sir Edward Grey:—The answer to this and the two previous questions is that I have no information, but will make enquiry. With regard to female education, I have to refer the Hon. Member to Chapter 42 of Lord Cromer's Report for 1906.

Dr. Rutherford.—To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether there exists in Egypt and the Soudan, or in either and which of those countries, a royalty on the manufacture, importation, exportation, or sale of refined sugar ; if so, what if the amount of such royalty; and whether it is intended to abolish wholly, or to reduce to any and what extent, such royalty and to replace it by one upon refined sugar.

Sir Edward Grey I am not aware of the existence of any such royalty. I will enquire But, will regard to the latter part of the question, I must point out that it is for obvious reasons the rule in this country not to announce an intention to alter duties before a decision has been arrived at, and the same reasons would I assume be equally applicable to Egypt.

Dr. Rutherford.—To ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, whether, seeing that under the new Pharmacy Law of Egypt no power of search or seizure is given, he will advise the Egyptian Government to amend the Law so as to create such power as regards Datives, who form the great majority of the illicit vendors of poisons.
Sir Edward Grey :—It is not a case in which II. M. Government can interfere with the discretion of the Egyptian Government

div.head: "AL WATAN'S" EXPERIMENT.
div.p: Mustapha Pasha Kamel's initiative in founding an English edition of his Arabic newspaper is being followed by other vernacular journals. Yesterday 'Al Watan," the Coptic organ, began a partial reproduction of its contents in English. Our contemporary remarks :—

We enter to-day on a new phase in the his­tory of "Al Watan" by producing an English resume of our daily Arabic paper twice or more every week. This novel feature is an experiment perhaps a leap in the dark. If the experiment is approved by our readers we will make this English section a permanent daily feature, otherwise it will be discontinued and the world will hear of it no more.

The important relations between England and Egypt and the increasing number of those who wish to read facts about Egypt in the language of the ruling Power have induced us to start this innovation in the hope of giving a true and undistorted statement of the facts to those who cannot read "Al Watan" in its native tongue.

div.head: THE NATIONALIST "PUNCH."
div.p: One of the latest developments of vernacular journalism is the new weekly comic paper . "The Shadow of Shadows" (Khayal el Zill which has been started by Mr. Hafiz Awad the enterprising Editor of one of the leading Nationalist daily newspapers, "Al Minbar". This' new organ has a number of caricatures of a political character which, it is needless remarks, are invariably directed against the Occupation and its supporters. While some of the ideas conveyed are of a decidedly humerous nature yet the pictorial part of the paper is of the crudest character and the portrait are often hopelessly unlike the originals. But at any rate there is plenty of "go" in our net contemporary and the lessons of its illustration are brutally obvious, so it ought to be succesful.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressedby our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit-within certain necessary limits- free discussion.

div.head: CONSUL AND GLOBE TROTTER.
div.p: to the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette "
Dear Sir,—If you will give me space in your valuable paper I would like to expose the character of the Danish Consul.

I am a Danish journalist working my way around the world on a bet. When once in Greece, his Majesty King George had the kindness to make me a present of 200 francs and arriving here at Alexandria some time later with a severe inflammations of the lungs, I had £2 left of the aforesaid sum. Upon my arrival I at once went to the Danish Consul, Count Lavison, and requested him to send me to the hospital.

My reception at the Consulate was not at all pleasant I had almost 41 C. fever, but I was not offered a seat; next thing he searched my pockets and took the few cents I had. Now after five weeks stay at the hospital I to-day went to the Consulate expecting to get my money, but I was informed that my money was to be used to help to cover the hospital expenses! And I was thus left without a cent in my pocket. I would like to ask any honest English­man's opinion of this gentleman's conduct. I may state that the money was taken out of my pocket against my will without my being able to resist owing to my illness. Besides writing to the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs I intend to publish the whole story in all newspapers at Copenhagen.
Alfred G Anderson,
Globe-Trotter.
Alexandria, April 26.

div.head: DOG SHOOTING.
div.p: To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette."

Sir, —May I through your valuable columns ask two questions ! (1) Are the Municipality employes authorised to shoot valuable pups? (2) Are the said employes within their rights to shoot the said pup within 4 metres of his home on a dahabieh moored to the banks of the Mahmoudieh Canal 7?

My reason for asking the above questions is that a pup of 4 months old, that was much valued both for its breeding and good qualities as a sporting dog, was shot within the above distance of its home, the dahabieh, by a man who gave his name as Fuller. The poor little pup had just had its bath and was let out for a run in the sun. It already showed good quali­ties and was a game little beast, being a good water dog, and fetched and carried splendidly.
I enclose my card and remain,—Yours faithfully. An Englishman.

div.head: THE HERNZTEIN CASE.
div.p: The hearing of the libel action brought by Mr. Hernztein against sixty-three Italian subjects was resumed yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock in the hall of the Appeal Court of the Mixed Tribunals., Over a thousand persons were estimated to have filled the hall in order to follow the pleadings, as the case has excited a great deal of local interest Maitres Luzzato and Colucci pleaded that Article 88 of the Italian Penal Code provided that in the case of a collective indictment a partial renunciation entailed the acquitted of all. The Court there­fore acquitted all the defendants amid great applause.

div.head: RIDICULOUS RUMOURS.
div.p: While the Cairo newspapers take the Alex­andrians severely to task for believing wild rumours as to the state of affairs in the Capital, they in their tum publish extraordinary ru­mours as to the state of affairs in the neigh­bourhood of Alexandria The "Journal du Caire" in its issue of yesterday remarks:—

Deux cents kilometres suffisent a singulierement feconder les esprits. A Alexandria en effet les bruits les plus extraordinaires courent sur la situation ici: on parle du Vieux-Caire, bomborde de la Citadelle, detruite, du canon ne ceasant de grander pour ecraser l'emeute et de... Moustafa Kamel proclame vice-roi sans doute.

Les Alexandria peuvent se rasaurer, et les loustics couper les ailes A leur fantaisie, la ville est si cal me qua sauf la tragique explo­sion d'hier, on n'a aucun incident A enregistrer et les reporters sontaur les dents.
On the other hand this morning's issue of Egypt says:-

Le bruit circule A Alexandria qu'une caravane portent 5,000 fusils Martini a ete artetee par la police du desert au Mariout. On suppose que ces armes etaient destinies aux tribus bedouines parmi lesquelles on constate depuis quelques temps une certaine effervescence.
Quoique cette nouvelle n'ait encore rien d'officiel, il n'en a pas fallu davantage pour effrayer la population europlenne de la ville quele moindre bruit alarmiate jette dans le desarroi.

Pour notre part, nons pensons que la deci­sion du gouvernement de renforcer les postes de douaniers garde-cotes dans le desert. coincidant avec la nouvelle de Londres annoncant une saisie d'armes dans la Tyneside division,
a contribue pour beaucoup a crier cet etat d'esprit.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Prince Frederick Heinrich of Prussia, son of the late Prince Albert of Prussia, who has been staying in Egypt for the past two months under the incognito of Graf von Muers, left Cairo yesterday for Port Said and embarked in the afternoon for Palestine.
Lord Cromer was received in private audience by the Khedive at Abdeen Palace this morning.
Sir Eldon Gorst will be received in private audience by the Khedive this afternoon.
Abani Pasha, Minister of War, has returned to Cairo from Alexandria.
Moustapha Pasha Ibadi, who is in Cairo, will return to Alexandria to-morrow.
Captain Lyons, director of the Survey Department, is leaving for London on May 5.
Major D. K. E. Hall, R. E., goods' manager of the Egyptian State Railways, is going on leave on the 3rd prox. He will spend his holiday in Switzerland.
The Rev. T. J. Hardy, senior chaplain (C. E) to the forces, and Mrs. Hardy will embark for London on the Bibby S S. Wor­cestershire to-morrow.
M. Brunei, who has been sent to Egypt on a mission by the French Ministry of Public Inst­ruction in order to study Moslem Universities, las arrived at Cairo.

Among the latest Arrivals at the Savoy hotel, Port Said, we notice : H R.H. Prince Benya, Comte G H. div.head: THE SINAI PENINSULA
div.p: Naoum Bey Choukair, Chief of the His­torical section of the War Office, returned to Cairo from Nakhl on the Sinaitic frontier on Thursday. He has been on a mission on behalf of the Egyptian Government in re­gard to the administration of the Peninsula of Sinai.

Up to recent times, the Sinai Peninsula has been under a dual control. The northern part, comprising the Governorate of El-Arish, has been under the Ministry of the Interior, whilst the central and southern portions of the Peninsula have been under the War Office, All the Sheikhs on the frontier are now anxious to have some recognized official near at hand, to whom they can refer disputes of minor importance. Many such cases occur and if they are not settled speedily they are liable to lead to serious trouble, and ever bloodshed. It has now been decided to bring the whole of the Peninsula under the Wai Department. A British officer of the Egyptian army will be Moudir and Commandant. His head-quarters will be at Nakhl. Egyptian Nazirs will be stationed at various points it the Peninsula. It is also proposed to appoint a British Inspector, whose head-quarters will probably be El-Arish.

During the present year, the system of administration which has up to the present time been in force will be continued, with om important exception, namely, that stops will be taken to get into touch with the Arabs ii the more remote parts of the Peninsula, am to bring them under some sort of control.

In Lord Cromer's penultimate Annual Report he gave a brief description of the very primitive system of justice which exist amongst the Bedouins in the Sinai Peninsula It is founded on old tribal custom. It is no proposed to interfere with this system beyond what is necessary to insure the adoption of few of the most elementary principles of equity and justice. Thus, a Judge, who is termed "El Mubasha," decides by the light of the dreams which may come to him in his sleep whether a person accused of any crime is guilty or innocent. It will perhaps not invole the too rapid introduction of civilized processes if this functionary is requested for the future to decide by the light of any informtion which may reach him while he is awake.
An additional sum of about £E.7,000 has been provided in the estimates for the current year in order to meet the charges consequent on the improvements in the Administration.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Bontigny
NOTES ET CRITIQUES
div.p: Les Caire, V n lredi 26 Avril 1907.

Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres reste à 3 1 8 pour cent. Au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglaisa baissé hier de 1/8 à 85 8/4. L'Unifiée a haussé de 1/4 à 102 1,4. La Na­tional Bank a perdu 1,4 à 23 8/4, l'Agricole 1,8 à 8 6/8 et la Daïra 1/8 à 16 3,8. '
A Paris, le Crédit Foncier Egyptien u re­gagné 2 francs à 725. La Banque d Athènes a rétrogradé de 1 franc à 123.

Ici, le marché des valeurs continue à être inactif par suite de l'effet calmant déterminé par les mesures extraordinaires décrétées le 22 Avril courant. U y a eu tout au plus, ce matin, deux douzaines de transactions. Cette situation semble être appelée à se prolonger jusqu'après la liquidation de fin courant à Ale­xandrie, qui, à cause des fêtes de Pâques orthodoxes, ne pourra être terminée que vers le 10 Mai prochain.

Le marché a été désagréablement impres­sionné par la nouvelle qu'une agence de cour­tage bien connue du Caire a dû déposer au­jourd'hui son bilan. Cette suspension de paie­ments atteindrait principalement les banquiers reporteurs. Des rumeurs ont circulé relative­ment à la situation de deux ou trois autres agences ; mais elles n'ont pas, heureusement, été confirmées.

Un télégramme de Paris a été lu en cor­beille annonçant que les titres égyptiens vendus a-bas sur des ordres transmis d'ici étaient achetés par des capitalistes et que les cours opposaient» par conséquent, une résistance efficace. On aurait reçu des dépêches tout aussi rassurantes de Londres.
Le marché des valeurs étant fermé les sa­medis pendant la saison d'été, le prochain numéro de notre Circulaire ne paraîtra que le lundi 29 Avril courant.
L'assemblée générale ordinaire de la Société d'Entreprises Immobilières et de Travaux a été tenue hier dans l'après-midi Les comptes et bilan du premier exercice ont été approuvés.

II résulte du rapport du conseil que la So­ciété a travaillé pendant l'exercice écoulé avec un capital moyen de L.E. 68,000,les appels de fonds ayant été faits à des intervalles assez éloignés. Les bénéfices totaux, amortissements divers déduits, 8e sont élevés à L.E. 18,212, ce qui représente plus de 24 % sur le capital versé.

Après le prélèvement-de 6 % pour la réserve et de l'intérêt statutaire de 7 % pour les ac­tions ordinaires, il est resté un solde de L. E. 12,052 à répartir comme suit : 10 % au conseil d'administration, 46 % aux actions ordinaires et 46 % aux parts de fondateur. Le dividende proposé est donc de P.E. 42 1/2 par action ordinaire et P. E. 6 par part de fondateur i vingt-cinquième). Les opérations immobilières de la Société ont été aussi fructueuses pour l'exercice en cours que pour l'exercice écoulé, ce qui permet eu conseil de proposer la ré­partition d'un dividende intérimaire de P. E. 21 par action ordinaire, portant le dividen le total à P.E. 63 1/2.
L'assemblée a approuvé toutes les proposi­tions du conseil et voté des remerciements aux administrateurs.

L'assemblée générale extraordinaire de l'E­pargne Immobilière Ltd., tenue hier après- midi, dans les bureaux de la Société au Caire, rue Soliman Pacha, a confirmé, à l'unanimité des voix, les modifications à divers articles des Statuts approuvées par l'assemblée extraor­dinaire du 10 Avril courant.

Une assemblée générale extraordinaire de l'Egyptian Delta Land and Investiront Co. est convoquée à Londres pour le 7 Mai prochain à l'effet de confirmer les résolutions spéciales approuvées par l'assemblée extraordinaire tenue le 16 Avril courant.
Carnet de l'actionnaire.

Un avis de la Société d'Entreprises Immo­bilières et de Travaux informe les actionnaires: 1*. Qu'à partir du 29 Avril courant il leur sera payé P.E. 42 1/2 par action contre remise du coupon No. 1, et P.E. 21 contre remise du coupon No. 2 ; 2*. Que le dernier versement Vur les actions, soit L E. 1 par titre, est exigible à partir du 29 courant. Les titres défini­tifs seront délivrés en même temps contre re­mise des certificats provisoires. La somme de P.E 6 par part de fondateur (vingt-cinquième) sera également payée, au siège social, à partir du 29 courant, contre remise du coupon No. 1.

— Les détenteurs de titres au porteur d'ac­tions ordinaires de la Walker and Meimarachi Ltd de la nouvelle émission sont informés que le coupon No. 4 portant intérêts est actuelle­ment payable à Londres à raison de 5 % l'an à partir de la date à laquelle les versements ont été effectués jusqu'au 30 Avril 1906.

GERMAN NAVY LEAGUE.

div.p: The Navy League has renewed its agitation for an increase in the navy. A statement has Wen issued dwelling on the danger of King Erdward's activity in the Mediterranean. (R )

AMBASSADORS SIGN PROTOCOL.

div.p: The Customs Protocol has been signed. (R.)

div.head:
THE ST LUCIA STRIKE.
MEASURES FOR SAFETY.

div.p: More Serious riots of coal porters are reported to have taken place at St. Lucia. Sugar estates have been burned. The riot act was read. The police fired killing 4 persons and wounding 19.
(Reuter)
The Governor has urgently appealed for assistance. 80 volunteers, with a maxim gun, and 20 police have been sent. (Reuter)

To-day's telegrams with regard to the strike at St. Lucia have been officially confirmed. The Governor of the Windward Islands has arrived at St. Lucia. He telegraphed yesterday evening that he hoped the back of the trouble had been broken and stated that a Dutch warship was in the harbour. The Admiralty are sending the Indefatigable.(Reuter)

The reports of the conclusion of an Anglo- Spanish naval alliance and of an Anglo- French-Italo-Spanish quadruple entente, which has agitated the German press, are authorita­tively denied here. (Reuter)

The French vice-consul at Bourgas has received a letter from the Macedonian com­mittee calling upon all the consuls to demand from their nations the payment of half the sum already asked for the needs of the comitadjis. The committee has threatened to blow up the consulates at Easter. (Havas)
The police have arrested seven signatories of anti-military notices. (Havas)
The rumoured threats of a general strike are denied.(Havas)
The Cabinet has passed the navy estimates providing for an annual increase of £600,000, during 8 years, for the purpose of strengthen­ing fortresses and the construction of ships.
(Reuter)
The German and Prussian issues of 4 % Treasury Bonds have been covered forty-five-foid: (Ruter)

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: Lieutenant Colonel Edward M. Esson, the new chief of the 1st Battalion of the "Green Howards," at Aldershot, takes over the battalion in order to prepare it for its approaching tour in Egypt. He has been connected with the old 19th for nearly twenty five years, having got his first appointment in May1882. Two years later, he went up the Nile with his present battalion, which was employed on the lines of communi­cations, and in the South African War, he commanded a company in the same battalion, and shared in the operations round Colesberg, the march along the Modder, the sharp actions which marked the advance of Roberts at Paardeberg, Poplar Grove, and Dreifontein: the capture of Bloemfontein, the advance on Dewetsdorp, the engagement at Leeuwkop the actions at Vet and Zand Rivers, Brandfort, Kroonstad, Johannesburg and Pretoria ; the engagements at Diamond Hill, and Belfast, etc., and the weary work in the Crocodile Valle)', where the malaria played such havoc amongst the Green Howards. For his services, Lieutenant Colonel Essen was mentioned in despatches, and received the Queen's medal with six clasps, and the King's medal with two clasps.

Major E. S. Strickland, 2nd Battalion Royal Dublin Fusiliers, Fermoy, has retired from the army, in which lie served from 1881, when lie was appointed to the 64th Regiment. He served with the North Staffords in the Zululand operations of 1888.
London, April 16.
Major A. E. Haig, King's Own, Scottish Borderers, on return to regimental duty, from the appointment of staff captain at head­quarters, has been posted to the 1st Battalion, at Cairo.

Major W. W. Cordeaux, second in command of the 21st Lancers, an officer well known in Cairo and Alexandria, is about to leave the service. He has served with the 21st from 1895, when he was promoted captain from the Queen's Bays—and prior to joining the Bays served in the Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers— charged with them at Omdurman.
The arrangements for the home artillery practice camps have been upset by the War Office, for what particular reason is not known.

Mr. Haldane's claim for the cheaper soldier works out someway in this manner. The cavalry soldier is to cast the country £72 per annum, instead of £78 ; the infantryman will cast £41 19s. 4d. instead of £53 16s, the royal field artilleryman will cost £45 12s as compared to his previous cost of £74 7s. 4d.
Lord Charles Beresford has taken over the command of the Channel Fleet, and flies his flag on the battleship King Edward VII.

The big armoured cruiser Invincible, which has just been launched at Elswick, will, when completed, he the largest cruiser afloat So secret have her details been kept, that very' little is known about her. All that has been made public is that she measures 530 feet in length, has a beam of 78$ feet, and a displace­ment of 17,250 tons, and will be able to carry 1,000 tons of coal. Two sister cruisers are being built on the Clyde, and practically the trio will be fast battleships. It is understood that the Invincible will be ready for the pennant inside a year from now. The new cruisers are longer by 50 feet than any others in the Royal

The "Medical Press" remarks : "We wonder if medical science will be called upon to advise as to the scientific treatment of the soldier. If so, one of the first things to go by the board will mostly likely be the erect hearing and puffed out military chest."

POLO MATCH.
A polo match was played at Gbezireh last Saturday between the Abbassia Hunt and the K S.C. The Hunt were well represented and won somewhat easily by 7 goals to 2.
Teams were as follows.
Abbassia Hunt. K.SC.
Mr. Dudgeon I. Capt Sterling I.
Major Gillson II. „ Gordon II. ,
Capt. Bartlett III. Mr. Marsham III.
Major Haig (back) Capt. Dunbar (back).
First Chukker.—K.S.C. were the first to score and had rather the best of the game the first period.
Second Chukker.—The Hunt found their game and playing well together scored 3 goals.
Third Chukker.—The Hunt, added two more, the K.S.C. also registering their second goal |

Fourth Chukker.—The Hunt scored 2 excellent goals, one being a magnificent shot by Major Neil Haig. For the winners Major Gill- son, the M.F.H. played a sound useful game and Mr Dudgeon was quite at his best at No.1. And with Major Haig and Capt Bartlett behind, the K.S.C. were lucky not to have a dozen goals scored against them.

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET.
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEKKLY REPORT
Liverpool, April 18.

We have again to report a very poor demand or Spot Egyptians, the market being depressed and quotations reduced 3/8d. p lb. for Fair Brown and 1/4 d. p lb. all other qualities In Futures a moderate business has beendone and the latest values are :—
April 10.16 July 10.2 Oct 9.58 Jan 9.37 May 10.8 Aug, 9.62 Nov. 9.46 June J0.4 Sept 9.60 Dec. 9.39

American Futures. The market this week 1 vas somewhat more active early in the reek, and prices advanced 8 @10 points for he Old, and 5 @ 6 tor the New Crop positions later it relapsed into a dull and inanimate condition, and the greater portion of the improvement has been lost. To-day's closing rallies are 1$@3$ points above those of last Thursday. There is absolutely no new feature, here is absolutely no fresh speculation, and apparently current-values so fit the situation, that it possesses, for the moment, no interest or either buyers or sellers.
Cold dry weather conditions have prevailed throughout the cotton belt until yesterday, when rains seem to have been fairly general, but the temperature remains low.

div.head: Coton.
div.p: Nous étions pleinement dans le vrai Ven­dredi dernier en disant que la position du Mai était encore surchargée et que la baisse n'avait pits dit son dernier mot : les événements de la semaine se' sont chargés de justifier notre opinion. Mais en même temps nous n'hésitons pas à déclarer que jamais, au grand jamais, nous n'avons songé à la possibilité d'une dé­bandade comme celle que nous avons eue, et les choses se sont passées avec une telle préci­tation, que nous sommes encore à nous de­mander si nous ne nous sommes pas trouvés après tout en face d'un rêve.

Certes, il y a longtemps que nous sommes habitué aux exagérations de notre place, mais cette lois notre surprise a été réelle, et la raison en est qu'après plus de 5 tallaris de baisse, celle-ci ne pouvait, à notre avis s'accentuer de beaucoup, même avec des réalisations d'une certaine importance, d'autant plus que l'exportation avaient déjà montré des dispositions aux achats. Seulement, aujourd'hui le fait est acquis, les positions sur Mai étaient beaucoup plus lourdes qu'on le pensait et les détenteurs qui servent trouvés dans l'obligation de liqui­der, avant tout à finir, sans regarder à unersaction près.

Ce sèraient done là les véritables raisons qui ont amené ce sauve qui-peut auquel nous avons assisté et qui nous a valu une espèce de panique qui, à son tour, aurait pu avoir pour notre place des conséquences assez graves. Mais, fort heureusement encore, notre com­merce d'exportation s'est trouvé à point pour sauver la situation : Sans se laisser influencer par l'horrible tendance du marché et n'envisa­geant la question qu'au seul point de vue du bon marché et' de sa convenance, il s'est livré à de véritables rafles de Mai et ce sont ces rafles mêmes qui ont dégagé et soulagé la situation. Nous reviendrons, du reste, un peu plus loin sur ce point.
En attendant voici l'historique succint de la semaine :•

Sans être réellement chaude, l'ouverture de samedi a été bonne, mais ce sont les bruits, ' répandus avec insistance, que de gros bonnets spéculateurs avaient pris leurs mesures pour 1st réception du Mai, qui ont fini, au fond, par influencer le marché qui clôtura à 19 3/16

Le leudemain, les meneurs du marché ont voulu encore une fois exploiter la même note. Pour un moment, ils ont paru réus­sir, mais dès que des ordres de vente sur Mai ont commencé à venir, les acheteurs qui criaient le plus fort se sont éclipsés et leur retraite a naturellement refroidi la ten­dance, ce qui nous fit perdre toute l'avance du matin et nous valut une clôture en perte de 1/8 sur la veille.

Cette tenue peu brillante influença la spé­culation a one façon extraordinaire et eut pour conséquent de nous attirer une quantité for­midable de réalisations en Mai, d'où la chute à 1h 15 3S pour le mois en question.
Mercredi, les choses ont plus mal marché encore et ce n'est qu'avec difficulté et grace aux gros achats de l'exportation que le cours de 18 1/8 a pu être maintenu.

Hier, an lieu d'une reprise, c'est encore de la baisse que nous avons eue et cette fois ' elle a atteint son apogée, le Mai ayant fini par 1 tomber à 17 3/4 et c'est à ce point que l'action du Commerce s'est fait sentir.

L'attraction du bon marché le fit rentrer en scène et comme en définitive le Mai était à 1 près de 1/2 tallari au-dessous du Novembre, il profita de la circonstance pour faire des échanges qui, tout en lui assurant un bénéfice qui tait pas à dédaigner, lui laissait libre entre les mains un stock de lionnes qualités-et de nature à lui faciliter les affaires avec la filature. Ses opérations en outre ne se limitèrent pas aux échanges, car il y a eu beaucoup d'achats purs et simples et même, en partie, ils consis­taient en du Juillet En clôture le ton était meilleur.

Mais en vérité, ce n'est qu'aujourd'hui que la reprise s'est accrue en atteignant 1 /4 de tallari et cela malgré la réserve des exporta­tions qui, n'ayant pu ni eu le temp3 de passer à la consommation tous leurs achats anté­rieurs, se sont trouvés forcés de limiter leur intérêt aux achats. Toutefois, cette réserve n'a pas empêché le soutien des prix, un tas de petits spéculateurs ayant jugé opportun de s'intéresser derechef à l'article.

L'inspiration est heureuse, car, après tout, qui est celui qui a pu espérer le cours de 18 tallaris après celui de 24 ? Il est incontestable qu'aujourd'hui nous sommes à très bon marché et qu'indépendamment de toute réaction natu­relle après une pareille chûte, le niveau actuel offre de la chance pour une hausse, non rapide et exagérée, mais graduelle et modérée. Nous avons soutenu pendant plusieurs semaines et depuis longtemps, que le seul remède à la fausse situation qui avait été créée par la spé­culation à la hausse proviendrait du nivelement du Mai avec le Novembre ; lé fait s'est non seulement produit, mais la vieille récolte est encore tombée au dessous de la nouvelle, et, par conséquent, à notre manière de juger les choses, l'acheteur de la récolte actuelle a, forcément, quelques atouts en sa favear.

Si la filature procède lentement encore, elle a néanmoins acheté, continue à acheter et finira bien à un moment donné par tout ra­masser et c'est cette perspective qui constitue le principal encouragement.
Comme résumé de tout le mouvement de la semaine nous nous trouvons aujourd'hui avec le Mai à 18 3/32, ce qui nous fait 29/32 de perdu sur Vendredi dernier.

Le Novembre, qui n'était soumis à aucune obligation de liquidation, a en une meilleure tenue que la vieille récolté et le cours de 18 7/16 affiché en clôture ne nous montre au total que 15/32 de perte sur la semaine passée.
Quant à l'activité elle a été des plus satis­faisantes dans son ensemble et elle a porté plus spécialement sur les échéances rappro-
chées à cause naturellement, de l'énormité des réalisations cairotes surtout.

Du côté de l'Amérique nous n'avous rien de saillant. De la hausse nous a été signalée et ensuite de la baisse, mais la tendance parait être pour une amélioration ultérieure à cause de certaines difficultés que l'on prévoit pour les vendeurs à la liquidation Mai. Toutefois on ne saurait aller bien loin, l'abondance de la marchandise étant de nature à entraver les efforts de la spéculation, aussi, pour le moment les cours de 6 pence semble-t il être le maxi­mum visé ou espéré par les détenteurs d'américain.

Le marché du disponible a été presque d'une nullité absolue, mais qui aurait pu s'attendre à une amélioration de la situation de ce côté avec les contrats en pleine désorganisation ? Du reste, chaque exportateur a son stock et pour les besoins de ses embarquements il n'a qu'en disposer en rachetant ses contrats.

Anjourd'hui pourtant, il y a eu un semblant d'animation' provenant, non de ventes effec­tives, mais d'échanges avec des arbitragistes reprenant leurs contrats à des conditions déterminées, contre la marchandise qu'ils cédaient.

Comme prix, la cote a été réduite de 1 tallari pour les Mit Affifi, de 5/8 pour les provenances Haute-Egypte, à l'exception du Good qui a été abaissé d'un tallari, et, finalement de 1/2 tallari pour le Ioannovich.

Du côté des exportations, il y a eu augmenta­tion sensible sur les premières prévisions et le total de la semaine a fini par s'élever à 8000 Balles, contre «300 l'année dernière, pour la même période.

Certes la laisse a facilité las affaires et à ce point de vue, les pronostics pour la semaine prochaine vont en s'améliorant ; seulement, il ne faut pas croire aux gros chiffres que l'on entend à la Bourse ; la semaine sera bonne, mais il ne faut pas oublier que la comparaison sera à faire avec 13500 Balles pour l'année dernière. 1

Liverpool n'a pas été encourageant pour les égyptiens disponibles, ni comme ventes, généralement de 100 Balles par jour, ni sons le rapport des prix qui ont baissé de 3/8 pour le spot, actuellement coté à 10 1/16. Les futars, pour leur part, ont été maltrai­tés dans tes mêmes proportions, le cours du Mai étant tombé à 9 49/64 soit 23/64 de baisse.

Les Américains disponibles par contre, ont été assez animés et finissent à 6,39 le spot, soit 11 points de hausse, tandis que les futurs ne gagnent que 5 et 3 points à la cote de 5.86 pour le Mai-Juin et 5.63 pour l'octobre- Novembre.

Les nouvelles alarmantes qui courent à la bourse au sujet de notre récolte n'ont pas leur raison d'être L'Alexandria General Produce Association a déjà reçu quelques réponses à ! son questionnaire d'Avril et quoique un retard de 15 à 20 jours soit admis, on donne la plante comme étant saine. Le retard en géneral est considéré comme un mal, mais le Dieu Soleil peut remédier à beaucoup de choses durant cet été.

div.head: Graines de Coton
div.p: Les recettes sont importantes pour la saison, mais on s'yattendait a cause de lu quantité plus forte que d'habitude, retenue dans l'intérieur pour compte de quelques maisons d'exportation.

Toutefois, ce n'est pas là la raison de la ré­action de cette semaine, car les embarquements sont plus forts encore, mais c'est bien à la faiblesse des contrats que nous la devons. Le spot a fini ce matin à P.T. 75 1/2.

En contrats, il n'y a que très peu d'affaires et le Mai, qui était à P T. 78 1/4 à un moment donné a fini à P.T. 77 15 en passant par P.T. 1 77. La péculation a toute son attention dirigée vers le coton et néglige l'article ; d'autre part aussi, il y â manque de vendeurs.
La nouvelle récolte est toujours d'uné nullité absolue et là cote d'environ P.T. 67 est pour ainsi nominmale. Hull achète toujours, mais sans faire de bruit, Dernier cours £ 7,8 9.
Les 3 mois Nov. Janvier n'y sont pas cotés.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINACIERE
div.p: Rien d'intéreSsant à relever sur l'état actuel du marché, ri ce n'est une stagnation complète dans les affaires. Il est certain que l'absence de transactions est due en grande partie aux mesures de rigueur prises exceptionnellement par le Comité de l'Association, mais il n'en est pas moins vrai que ces mesures s'imposaient devant le désarroi du marché provoqué par l'an antissement de cette spéculation à qui l'Egypte doit en partie sa prospérité matérielle. En effet celle-ci vient de perdre, plus de 2 millions de livres par suite de la dégrin­golade récente des cotons D'autre part, la dépréciation des terrains achetés dans les faubourgs du Caire et celle résultant des va­leurs égyptiennes, qui s'élève à l'heure actuelle à pris de 10 millions de livres, constituent autant de pertes désastreuses pour la spécula­tion—naguère si forte—et aujourd'hui, vouée à l'impuissance.

La situation actuelle est néammoins loin d'être alarmante, nous avons le ferme espoir que les affaires s'amélioreront ; mais faut il aussi laisser le temps à la spéculation de se ressaisir et de fournir les moyens aux capita­listes d'absorber le flottant qui pèse tant sur nos marchés.

Nous sommes heureux de constater le succès éclatant remporté par certaines nouvelles émis­sions dans les conditions actuelles du marché Il • y a là un symptôme très satisfaisant qui fait Mien présager de l'avenir.
Au Caire un accord a été signé entre les Agents de Change et les principaux reporteurs en vertu duquel ces derniers s'engagent à

transformer en compte courant tous les dos­siers qu'ils ont en report à l'échéance de fin courant, moyennant un intérêt de7à9l'an pour le minimum d'un mois, à la condition que les différences de compensation soient payées par les emprunteurs.

La compensation sera celle qui a été fixée par le comité le lundi 22 courant. Le compte courant, dans le cas spécial sera ouvert sans marge. Par contre, les agents s'engagent à faire par l'intermédiaire de leur Comité les démarches nécessaires pour éviter toute nou­velle émission.
La Banque d'Angleterre vient de réduire le taux d'escompte à 4%, son encaisse progresse à £34,395,000 et la proportion des réserves aux engagements s'améliore encore et passe de 44 5/8 % à 45 3/8 %.
La première assemblée générale ordinaire de la Cairo Electric Railways and Heliopolis Oasis Company est convoquée pour le 21 du mois prochain, au siège social, au Caire.

Une assemblée générale extraordinaire sera tenue aussitôt après pour approuver plusieurs décisions et la convention passée avec le gou­vernement relativement à la construction d'habitations destinées aux employés.

L'Assemblée générale extraordinaire de la Société Anonyme des Ciments d'Egypte tenue le 20 Avril courant à Bruxelles, a adopté à l'unanimité des voix, les propositions tendant à la réduction du capital social et à sa recons­titution par une émission de 15.000 actions nouvelles de 50 francs chaque-

Deux nouvelles sociétés égyptiennes vien­nent d'être enregistrées à Londres : l'Egyptian Produce and Navigation Company au capital de £100,000 divisé en 24.812 actions ordinaires de £4 chaque et 15,040 deferred de 1 schelling chaque. Les fondateurs sont : Mahmoud Bey Khalil, MM. F.R. Dreux, J. Gerard, L. Causse, etc. L'autre Société est l'United Delta Engineers an capital de £200.000, divisé en 195,400 actions ordinaires de £1 et 12,000 deferred de lsh., pour entreprendre en Egypte et au Soudan des travaux de mécanique, marine, gaz, électrecité, agriculture, fourniture d'eau, irrigation, travaux techniques, chemins de fer et travaux publics.

L'Anglo-Belgian Company of Egypt a acquis il y a quelque temps un terrain à Choubrah, le long de la route du tramway. Ce terrain a été divisé en 22 parcelles, sur les­quelles on va établir des villas. Le projet a été favorablement accueilli par le public au Caire, et la majorité des parcelles ont été déjà placées
La Compagnie Immobilière vient de vendre 9.000 métrés environ du terrain ayant fait partie de l'ex-propriété Sabet Menasce.
La Compagnie avait acquis celle-ci au prix moyen de L.E 7 per métré. La vente ayant été faite au prix de LE 36 par métré, le bénéfice et de L.E. 29, soit au total L,E. 81.000.

Jeudi dernier a eu lieu chez MM. H. de Vries et Boutigny, l'assemblée générale annuelle Je la Société d'Entreprisee Immobilières et Travaux. La séance était présidée par Me Colucci, administrateur. Scrutateurs : MM. Lantié et Loret, choisis parmi les plus forts actionnaires présents. 19.750 actions sur 25.000 étant représentées, l'assemblée est légalement constituée.

Il résulte du rapport du Conseil d'administra­tion que la Société a travaillé pendant l'exercice écoulé avec un capital moyen de L.E. 58,000, les appels de fonds ayant été faite à des in­tervalles assez éloignés. Le bénéfice total, amortissements divers déduits, s'élève à Lst. 18212, ce qui représente plus du 24% sur le capital versé. Après un prélèvement de 5% pour la réserve statutaire et 7% intérêt statu taire pour les actions ordinaires, il ruste un solde de Lst. 12052 ù répartir comme suit : 10% au conseil d'administration, 45% aux actions ordinaires et 45% aux parts de fon­dateur. Le dividende proposé est de P.T. 421/2 par action ordinaire et P.T. 6 par part de fon­dateur (vingt cinquième).

Le rapport parlant des affaires de la Société annonce que les opérations immobilières de la Société ont été des plus fructueuses, tant pour l'exercice écoulé que pour celui en cours, ce qui permet d'ores et déjà au conseil d'administra­tion de proposer la distribution d'un dividende intérimaire de P.T. 21 par action ordinaire à ajouter au coupon échu, soit un total de P.T. 63 1/2.

La Société est engagée dans diverses affaires qui lui assurent un bénéfice considérable pour l'exercice actuel ; noua citerons pour mémoire, la société des terrains de Cléopatra, et l'Epargne Immobilière Ldt, dont 5000 parts de fondateur lui ont été attribuée* et qui présenteront par la suite une recette importante.

La Société d'Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux a réalisé aussi de notables bénéfices sur des affaires de courtages entr'autres pour la Ghezireh Land dont elle fut le principal courtier, avantage qu'elle doit à la maison de Vries et Boutigny.
Le Conseil propose ensuite de confirmer Mtre Lakah dans ses fonctions d'administra­teur et de réélire les censeurs (MM. Russell, Kerr et Wyatt).
Toutes les propositions du conseil d'ad­ministration ayant été adoptées à l'unanimité, la séance a été levée après un vote de remercie­ments au Conseil d'administration.

"Investments" introduces, in an entirely original manner, new and important methods for the employment of and the means of obtaining capital. Among the
SPECIALLY CONTRIBUTED ARTICLES
are "Stock Markets and How to Profit by Them"; "Theory of Successful Speculation"; "How to start an Account" ; "The Advantages of 'Call Options'"; "Contangoing Mining and Industrial Securities" ; "How to Invest in Mines"; "American Rails, with Points for Operators in Yankees"; "The Purchase of Investment Securities by Instalments" ; "General Principles for Investors" ; "Rules for Investors in Mines"; "General Principles for Speculators"; "Stock Exchange Terms," being a glossary for Market Operators; "Stock Exchange Parlance"; "Insurance, as a Means of Making, Raising, and Saving Money," and "Colonial Building Land: Its Great Possibilities."

div.head: CINEMAPHON AZIZ AND DORES
div.p: Le succès bat son plein. Les représentations continuent à attirer une foule aussi élégante que nombreuse. Le clou de cette semaine est sans conteste la grande scène dramatique "The Train Wreckers" qui est très émouvante et fort bien réussie. Le reste du programme est très attrayant et très original.

NOTICE
div.p: Person importing Egyptian Labourers to work in the Sudan are reco,,emded to enter into a written contract with them.This contract should be explained and signed by the Labour yers in pressence of an offical or other reliable witness.
The Egyptian Delta Land& Investment Company, Limited.

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an Extraordinary general Meeting of the above Company will be held at Winchester , House, Old Broad Street, in the City of Lon­don, on Tuesday, the 7th flay of May, 1907, at 12 o'clock noon, for the purpose of considering, and if thought fit, confirming the following Resolutions, which were duly passed at an Extraordinary General Meeting of the Com­pany on the 16th day of April, 1907, so that the same shall, become and be Special Resolu­tions ;—
SPECIAL RESOLUTIONS.

Old Broad Street, E.C., t Dated 19th April, 1907. Shareholders who hold Warranta to Bearer are reminded that if they wish to attend the Extraordinary General Meeting of the Com­pany they must first deposit their Hearer Warrants, together with a statement in writ­ing of their names and addresses, either at the Registered Office of the Company in London, two clear days before the Meeting, if, not later than the 4th May, or in Egypt with the National Bank of Egypt, the Bank of Egypt, the Anglo-Egyptian Rank, Limited, Credit Lyonnais, or the Imperial Ottoman Bank, ten clear days before the date of the meeting, i.e., not later than 26th April, the Share Warrants remaining so deposited until after the General Meeting shall have been held.
Each Depositor will receive a Certificate of Deposit in exchange for the Share Warrants deposited, which must be produced by the holders attending the Meeting.

div.head: ARMY OF OCCUPATION.
FORAGE.
div.p: Tenders will be received at the Head Quarters Office, Cairo, until 12 o'clock noon on Tuesday 30th April 1907, for the supply of Tibbin to the Army of Occupation at Cairo and Alexandria, for 12 months from the 1st June 1907.
Forms of Tender and all information may be obtained at the above office on application.
Envelopes containing Tenders should be addressed to
"The General Officer Commanding, Cairo."
and marked on the outside "Tender for Tibbin."
The General Officer Commanding does not bind himself to accept the lowest or any Tender,
E.R.O. Ludlow, Lieut: Colonel, Commanding A.S.C. in Egypt.
Municipalité d'Alexandrie
AVIS

Le Mardi 80 Avril courant de 10 h. du matin à midi laMunicipalité procédera à la venta aux enchères publiques près do fort No. 20 de Kom el Chougata El Batrani d'une quantité de 1000 mètres cubes environ des pierres (Kantaris, Mcellons, Dakehoum) pro­venant de la démolition dédit fut .
Ces pierres cout divsees en lot de 20 à 100 M 3.

Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d'enchetè e de 1 % et déposer le 10 % de la valeur de la marchandise achetée au moment de la vente et effeoter le paiemeut intégral à la Caise Municipale le lendemain du jour de l'adjudication.

Ils aurontà aopporter les droits de carrière an profil de la ville et devront enlever le* pierres achtées dans un délai de dix jours sont peine de folie enchère pour compte de l'edjudicataire et de perte du dépot de 10 %.
Alexandrie, le 20 Avril 1907.
L'Administrateur,
30106 3-3 (Sigué) W. P. Chataway.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It is simply weakness-a break-down. As it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be it causes (for they are almost numberless) its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. New, what alone is absolutley essential in all such cases is increased vitality-vigour-

Supplement Commercial et Finacier
DE
"L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"

Le Supplement Commercial et FInancier de l' "Egyptian Gazzette" parait chaque Samedi a midi, de facon a pouvoir etre expedie par le paquebot autrichian. Il contient des revues completes et impertiales du coton, des graines de coton, et du marche des valeurs; les dernieres statisques jusqu'a la veile de sa publication : des tableaux des fluctuations de la place et les copies des depeches officielles envoyees a la Liverpool Cotton Association e'c etc
L'abonnemeut pour une annee en Egypte coute 1 L.E. y compros les frais de poete; pour l'estranger 10 P.T. de port en sus.
